text:
The big question is what do you want to do with the files:

If you're using flumine to backtest then you can patch open with smart_open so it doesn't matter if your prices files are bz2 (historic) gzip (scraped) or uncompressed. It also handles reading directly from S3 and other cloud services.

If you just want a list of market book dictionaries:

```from betfairutil import read_prices_file
market_books = read_prices_file(path_to_prices_file)```
Again, the prices file can be compressed, uncompressed, in S3, stored locally, whatever.

If you just want to look at the file and you're on a Unix based operating system (including I assume Windows subsystem for Linux) then you can just do

```bzless historic_data_file.bz2```
in your terminal

elements.text:
The big question is what do you want to do with the files:

If you're using flumine to backtest then you can patch open with smart_open so it doesn't matter if your prices files are bz2 (historic) gzip (scraped) or uncompressed. It also handles reading directly from S3 and other cloud services.

If you just want a list of market book dictionaries:

from betfairutil import read_prices_file
market_books = read_prices_file(path_to_prices_file)

Again, the prices file can be compressed, uncompressed, in S3, stored locally, whatever.

If you just want to look at the file and you're on a Unix based operating system (including I assume Windows subsystem for Linux) then you can just do
bzless historic_data_file.bz2
in your terminal

text:
Personally I don't concern myself with roi as it's different at different odds and I don't think that for our purposes it makes sense to worry about it.

If you're just thinking about optimal staking / scaling I would just look directly at profit per bet. I just plot the stake against the profit and look at the curve  as compared to the curve of all bets fully matched. No need to worry about the actual match rates if that's all you're interested in.

I do look at the match rates if I'm trying to understand what a particular signal might be telling me.

elements.text:
Personally I don't concern myself with roi as it's different at different odds and I don't think that for our purposes it makes sense to worry about it.

If you're just thinking about optimal staking / scaling I would just look directly at profit per bet. I just plot the stake against the profit and look at the curve  as compared to the curve of all bets fully matched. No need to worry about the actual match rates if that's all you're interested in.

I do look at the match rates if I'm trying to understand what a particular signal might be telling me.

text: To be clear - there are circumstances where roi might be important but they don't really apply to my type of operation where you have more funds available than the market will bear and all you want to do is rinse every opportunity.

elements.text: To be clear - there are circumstances where roi might be important but they don't really apply to my type of operation where you have more funds available than the market will bear and all you want to do is rinse every opportunity.

<@UGV299K6H> once you've determined an optimal stake how do you go about monitoring that it's still the optimal stake once you start using that stake?  Do you still bet a range of stakes, albeit using a smaller range than you would have done when determining the optimal stake, so you can see if the optimal stake is changing over time?  Or do you assume once you've got the optimal stake it never changes and you just bet at that forever more?

text: Is just me who feel like this or do markets (horse racing/greyhounds) behave very differently on weekends vs weekdays?  I have several strategies that produce the complete opposite result on weekdays vs weekends. However, I don't have enough data to confirm whether this is just mere randomness.

elements.text: Is just me who feel like this or do markets (horse racing/greyhounds) behave very differently on weekends vs weekdays?  I have several strategies that produce the complete opposite result on weekdays vs weekends. However, I don't have enough data to confirm whether this is just mere randomness.

text: <@U01MPC0GUK1> yes I always randomise everything to a degree and just keep an eye on how stuff is doing over time. In general it doesn't change much though. My average stakes now are about the same as they were ten years ago.

elements.text: yes I always randomise everything to a degree and just keep an eye on how stuff is doing over time. In general it doesn't change much though. My average stakes now are about the same as they were ten years ago.

text: Most likely randomness. In my experience stuff like that never stands the test of time.

elements.text: Most likely randomness. In my experience stuff like that never stands the test of time.

text: What <@UGV299K6H> said. I've come up with rationales for this in the past, but they never stood up to formal, quantitative investigation.

elements.text: What
said. I've come up with rationales for this in the past, but they never stood up to formal, quantitative investigation.

text: Prices are moved by the amount of money being placed on track and in the bookies. Bookies are empty during the week but full at the weekends. So yes the markets are different at the weekends. (Quantitative investigation pmsl)

elements.text: Prices are moved by the amount of money being placed on track and in the bookies. Bookies are empty during the week but full at the weekends. So yes the markets are different at the weekends. (Quantitative investigation pmsl)

text: If that were the case it would simply correlate to bigger markets rather than weekends/weekdays which would be a proxy measure. That may be the case, but it's not what <@U0266A8579B> described.

elements.text: If that were the case it would simply correlate to bigger markets rather than weekends/weekdays which would be a proxy measure. That may be the case, but it's not what
described.

text:
I don't know about greyhounds, but the major horse races which take the most money on course, on the high street and on BF are mostly mid week. All books move with a degree of unison because of arbitrage but that's not a one way street, the interaction between the books and the exchanges runs in both directions.

It's also worth noting that there's almost no major racing on a Sunday.

elements.text:

It's also worth noting that there's almost no major racing on a Sunday.
